claim.claim-text: The antenna management method of claim 1, wherein the allocating wireless resources to all the wireless link clusters of the antenna scheduling set comprises: selecting an independently-scheduling link cluster group from all the wireless link clusters of the antenna scheduling set, wherein an antenna beam of each wireless link cluster in the independently-scheduling link cluster group is set such that interference between the wireless link cluster and each other wireless link cluster in the independently-scheduling link cluster group is within the predetermined range; allocating a bandwidth to each wireless link cluster in the independently-scheduling link cluster group; and repeating the selecting an independently-scheduling link cluster group and the allocating a bandwidth until first bandwidth requirements of all the wireless link clusters of the antenna scheduling set are satisfied.

The antenna management method of claim 2, further comprising: dividing each wireless link cluster into at least one bandwidth requirement region in the direction of a radiation radius of the wireless link cluster according to a coverage range of a power level of the wireless link cluster, wherein the bandwidth requirement of each bandwidth requirement region is the sum of the bandwidth requirements of all the wireless links in the wireless link cluster which contain a node in the bandwidth requirement region, and the sum of the bandwidth requirements of all the bandwidth requirement regions of the wireless link cluster is equal to the first bandwidth requirement of the wireless link cluster; and determining the bandwidth requirement of the bandwidth requirement region corresponding to the radiation radius of the currently set antenna beam of each wireless link cluster as the bandwidth requirement of the wireless link cluster at the current antenna beam setting of the wireless link cluster.

The antenna management method of claim 4, wherein the selecting a next candidate wireless link cluster to be added to the independently-scheduling link cluster group comprises: selecting from the remaining wireless link clusters of the antenna scheduling set a wireless link cluster which has the shortest exclusion distance from the initial wireless link cluster, as the next candidate wireless link cluster to be added to the independently-scheduling link cluster group, wherein the exclusion distance between two wireless link clusters refers to the smallest number of the wireless link clusters interfering with one another through which one of the two wireless link clusters needs to pass to reach the other of the two wireless link clusters.

The antenna management method of claim 4, wherein the setting the antenna beam of the next candidate wireless link cluster comprises: setting the power level of the next candidate wireless link cluster such that the interference between the next candidate wireless link cluster at said power level and each wireless link cluster existing in the independently-scheduling link cluster group is within the predetermined range; and setting the radiation radius of the antenna beam of the next candidate wireless link cluster to a radius corresponding to the coverage range of the power level.

The antenna management method of claim 4, wherein when the type of the transmitting antenna of the next candidate wireless link cluster is a smart antenna,
the setting the antenna beam of the next candidate wireless link cluster comprises: dividing a radiation angle of the antenna beam of the next candidate wireless link cluster into multiple sub-radiation angles; and setting the antenna beam of the next candidate wireless link cluster in each sub-radiation angle separately; and the antenna management method further comprises: combining the antenna beams in the multiple sub-radiation angles to obtain the antenna beam of the next candidate wireless link cluster if the antenna beam in each of the multiple sub-radiation angles can be set such that the interference between the next candidate wireless link cluster and each wireless link cluster existing in the independently-scheduling link cluster group is within the predetermined range.

The antenna management method of claim 7, wherein the combining comprises: combining the antenna beams in the multiple sub-radiation angles such that the antenna beam obtained by the combining has a largest radiation radius or a largest radiation angle.
The antenna management method of claim 7, wherein the combining comprises combining the antenna beams in the sub-radiation angles which have a bandwidth requirement.

The antenna management method of claim 2, wherein an initial value of the first bandwidth requirement of each forwarding link cluster among the wireless link clusters of the antenna scheduling set is set to zero, wherein the forwarding link cluster is a wireless link cluster between relay nodes; and
the antenna management method further comprises: determining a preceding link cluster of the forwarding link cluster; and increasing the first bandwidth requirement of the forwarding link cluster to a bandwidth allocated to the preceding link cluster of the forwarding link cluster when the preceding link cluster of the forwarding link cluster is selected into the independently-scheduling link cluster group and is allocated with the bandwidth.
The antenna management method of claim 1, wherein the collecting resource use information from managed access networks comprises: collecting resource use state data from the managed access networks.

The antenna management method of claim 12, wherein the collecting resource use information from managed access networks further comprises: collecting an antenna scheduling request from the managed access networks.

The antenna management method of claim 13, wherein the resource use state data and the antenna scheduling request are collected by sending an information collecting request periodically to the managed access networks; or the resource use state data and the antenna scheduling request are collected by receiving information data sent by the managed access networks on their own initiatives.

The antenna management method of claim 12, further comprising: determining the access networks which have a resource utilization rate lower than a predetermined threshold by analyzing the resource use state data; judging whether the resource utilization rate is lower due to interference; and initiating the forming an antenna scheduling set, the grouping into wireless link clusters and the allocating wireless resources if the resource utilization rate is lower due to interference.

The antenna management method of claim 1, further comprising: receiving pre-scheduling results from the managed access networks; and in allocating the wireless resources, avoiding an influence on the pre-scheduling result of the access network who has a high priority and who does not join the antenna scheduling, and allocating the wireless resource preferentially to the access network who has a high priority and who joins the antenna scheduling.
The antenna management method of claim 1, wherein the managed access networks comprise multiple heterogeneous access networks.

An antenna management apparatus, comprising: a resource use information collector configured to collect resource use information from managed access networks; and an antenna scheduler comprising: an antenna selector configured to select the access networks joining antenna scheduling from the managed access networks according to the resource use information to form an antenna scheduling set, wherein the access networks using the same spectrum resource form the same antenna scheduling set; a link cluster determiner configured to group wireless links of each access network in the antenna scheduling set into one or more wireless link clusters, wherein each wireless link cluster includes one or more wireless links of the same access network which have the same transmitting node or the same receiving node; and a resource scheduler configured to allocate wireless resources to all the wireless link clusters of the antenna scheduling set such that interference between all the wireless link clusters of the antenna scheduling set is within a predetermined range, and to send a wireless resource allocation result to the access network in which each wireless link cluster is located.
